data.title: NBC invests in web with iVillage deal
data.meta_description: 4pm: US media giant NBC Universal is to buy iVillage, the network of women's websites, for $600m (£340m). By Chris Tryhorn.
data.text:
US media giant NBC Universal is to buy iVillage, the network of women's websites, for $600m (£340m).

NBC Universal today revealed it would acquire iVillage, a New York-based business that was founded in 1995 and set up a British arm in 2000.

The network covers women's interest topics such as relationships, parenting, pregnancy, health, beauty and astrology.

The deal, which is to be completed in the second quarter of the year, is the latest attempt by established media companies to develop their web assets and make the internet integral to their business.

Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation spent a similar amount - $580m - on Intermix Media, the owner of online teenage network MySpace.com.

Viacom has bought an online games site, the iFilm short films site and is keen to invest in "social networking" websites.

NBC Universal is majority owned by General Electric and was formed from the merger of the NBC television network and the Universal entertainment assets once owned by French group Vivendi.
